awd_titl_txt: Establishing a common function for ferlin proteins in membrane    fusion    using    novel    genetic    code    expansion   and   single   molecule   techniques.
awd_abstract_narration:
Membrane trafficking is regarded as a crucial and distinctive characteristic of eukaryotic cells, with both intracellular transport and secretion events playing an essential role in homeostasis and signaling. While much of what is known about membrane trafficking comes from studies in yeast, there are important proteins involved in membrane trafficking in multicellular organisms not seen in yeast.  One family of these proteins are the ferlins, an evolutionarily ancient family of trafficking proteins linked to an increasingly diverse list of physiological activities, including fertility, the encoding of sound, muscle development, and repair of damaged cell membranes. This diversity of physiological roles has made establishing a common underlying molecular function for this family challenging. This project will address this gap in our knowledge of the Ferlin family proteins, and in so doing add to our understanding of fertility, hearing, and muscle development. The proposed work will also develop undergraduate laboratory research training opportunities and lab classes focused on membrane biology and provide graduate students with state-of-the-art training in interdisciplinary research.

The project tests the idea that ferlins share a common function as calcium sensitive scaffolds for regulated exocytosis and endocytosis. Challenges due to the large size of the proteins, their transmembrane domains, and the high number of endogenous cysteines typical of ferlins have precluded many of the traditional recombinant protein assays typically used to test this hypothetical function. To overcome these challenges a novel single molecule protein-protein interaction assay that allows for probing the contacts of large multivalent membrane proteins has been developed.  In addition, genetic code expansion techniques will be exploited to incorporate environmentally sensitive fluorescent unnatural amino acids into the ferlins. These technologies will be exploited to determine the  functions that underlie ferlin activity. The proposed studies will define a set of underlying molecular-level functions that unite the ferlins, despite their disparate physiological roles. This information will allow integrating ferlins into the larger picture of membrane trafficking and cell signaling. The development of a novel single molecule fluorescence technique will provide a method for the study of large multi-domain membrane proteins and thus have applications beyond the study of ferlins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated how the ferlin family of membrane proteins can fuse vesicles with the cell membrane.  Ferlin proteins are essential for physiological processes ranging from hearing, to wound repair, fertility, and muscle contraction. Mutations in ferlins are linked to pathologies that include deafness, muscular dystrophy, infertility, and cancer. Ferlins contribute to these processes by binding and fusing intracellular vesicles and releasing the contents into the extracellular environment. However despite their importance, there is no consensus on how ferlins work to bring about fusion, preventing a full understanding of their associated pathways. Using the vertebrate ferlins otoferlin, dysferlin, and myoferlin as models, we characterized the mechanism by which these proteins fuse membranes and determined ferlin-specific properties that explain functional differences between family members.

               Overall we found that ferlins appear to have a conserved membrane fusion activity within the “back” C-terminus of the protein and different protein-specific functions at the “front” N-terminus of the protein. Specifically we found that a folded domain at the N-terminus of dysferlin known as C2A serves an essential role in regulating the protein’s cell membrane repair activity, while other ferlins either possess a nonfunctional domain, or lack the folded domain. Our studies suggest that when dysferlin is inactive the domain is unfolded, and upon wounding of the cell the domain folds and binds the cell membrane, allowing for subsequent cell repair. We therefore proposed that this domain serves as a sensor that prevents activation of the protein until injury. By contrast, the C2A domain in other ferlins, like otoferlin, do not appear to regulate activity, indicating that this domain has changed among family members to meet the different needs of the protein family. Mutations in dysferlin are linked to human disease, and a comparison of normal and mutant variants of the dysferlin C2A domain revealed two underlying reasons for pathology. Pathological mutations in C2A appear to decrease expression of dysferlin to an amount insufficient for wound repair. However, we also found certain mutations abrogated the membrane binding properties of the domain, resulting in a protein that is not functional regardless of expression levels.

               Like dysferlin, otoferlin mediates vesicle fusion, however otoferlin is also responsible for regenerating vesicles after fusion. We found that in contrast to dysferlin, otoferlin does not bind membranes through the folded C2A at the N-terminus, but instead uses a linker between the folded C2A domain and the next domain C2B. This linker also binds  proteins involved in endocytosis, and based on our studies we conclude that linker binding to the membrane would help to recruit endocytotic proteins and accelerate vesicle regeneration. Truncation of this region of the protein results in vesicle resupply deficiencies, and our results provide an explanation for these observations. We also found that the dysferlin linker bound membranes weakly and may be responsible for a different activity relative to otoferlin.  

               During our studies we have refined our method for measuring protein-membrane interactions using a fluorescent unnatural amino acid. We incorporated the amino acid into positions on dysferlin C2A proposed to interact with membranes and mapped the C2A-membrane interface. Our studies revealed that the domain actually inserts into the membrane. These measurements convincingly demonstrated that dysferlin and otoferlin anchor to the cell membrane by inserting into the lipid layer. Collaborating with both NMR and computational biology experts we also determined the structure of the dysferlin domain in complex with the membrane. Our development and refinement of unnatural amino acids provides a valuable tool for the study of protein-membrane interaction.

               Part of the grant period overlapped with the covid epidemic which curtailed certain activities however multiple graduate and undergraduate students, as well as high school students and a postdoctoral researcher received research experience and training in biophysical and structural techniques. In addition to several published studies supported by this award, the project also served as the focus for two PhD dissertations.
